messageBody:
On 7/31/07, Nat Pryce <nat.pryce@...> wrote:
> And, may I add, that a technical solution to social problem is a poor
> substitute for a social solution to the social problem.

I'm not sure I understand that.

Using a sound implementation for a singleton (e.g. dependency
injection) is similar to leveraging the compiler to minimize mistakes:
I'd rather trust the compiler to enforce a good practice than vague
social recommendations that risk to be ignored for various reasons
(and even by the best developers).

> If members of the team don't understand the architecture then tech
> huddles and a big visible architecture diagram can help.

This is a very idealistic view of things. In teams of dozens of
programmers of various age and seniority levels scattered over
multiple time zones, mentoring and diagrams only go so far. The only
way to guarantee that things don't break is to leverage your
programming language to make sure that any infraction will simply not
compile.

> If the class names don't express the idea that there should only be
> one of a class in the production code then a tech huddle to agree on a
> system of names and a refactoring session can help.

Maybe for very tiny open source projects, but certainly not in
general, in my experience...
